cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

SATURDAY, JANUARY 11, 1908.

div.head: THE ORIENTAL RENAISSANCE.
div.p: The recent Indian National Congress has evoked a great number ot comments. "What- ever the outcome: of the present situation, there is no doubt that the merely contenip- tuous style of Anglo Indian criticism which was frequent. and to a large extent justified; & few years ago is no longer in place," writes the "Daily Telegraph." "One broud fact de- mocracy in this country must force-itself to realise The Russo-Japanese conflict was one of the greatest, as well as bloodiest, struggles éver fought in the world, and nothing in the relatious of East and West can ever be quite the same as it was before. These are grave words. Weusethem advisedly. We would fain beg for some attention to them. Upon the Manchorian plains and in the adjacent waters the armies, the fleets ofa great white Power went down before, an Asiatic adversary.

" At the sound of that amazing event a new epoch of history opened visibly. The Asiatic renaissance had begun+the awakening of those vast races, nambering eight hundred mil- lions of mankind, who have peopled the Mother of Continents from a period im- memorial ; who were the equals or the super- iors of the Western: nations in medieval civilisation ; and who have only been driven to acknowledge the scientific ascendency of the European intellect since a moment that seems like yesterday by comparison with the an- tiquity of their annals, Itis certain that the political and religious and social "consequences of the Asiatic renaissance will be far slower in the process than we are apt to think, though probably not less tremendous in the ultimate issue than even the boldest minds anticipate "

"The disorders at the lnudian National Con- gress this year will doubtless be made the text for many solemn lectures on the folly of any and 'every Liberal movement in India, but thoughtfal men will know bow little store to lay by them," says the "Manchester Guardian." "the Indian Congress has met every year since Lord Ripon ended his fanous Vicé- royalty, and always, till this year, in perfect order. Its greatest enemy has been the iudiffer- ence of English public opinion. But for this it would long ago have been recognised as one of the most important of our Imperial institu- tions."

"Such a situation makes an 'appeal of peculiar ecogency to the sympathy © of English Liberals," adds the "Guardian." "In more than twenty years Indian reformers, in the tace of obloquy and indifference, have gone on patientiy'aud soberly trying to apply the political ideals of Eaylishmen to the svlation of India's problems. One section, string iu numbers, though not in leaders, has now thrown over those id als in despair; the other section not only retains its faith io our principles, but it is prepared to break up the party in support of them

"Such loyalty is a rebuke to the imliffsrence of all but the c¢ mparatively sina l namber ot English Liberals who are interested in Indian afiairs; but itis also a call for help to which we cannot-imagine them turning a deaf ear. It would, indeed, be a bad day for Liberalism when loyalty to its principles in [udia failed to awaken an answering sense of .duty amongst English Liberals. The situation in India 1s now unmistakably clear. For a few years longer the fort can be held for thé cause of peacetu) and constitutional Liberal reform; but unless English Liberals také energetic action for its assistance, thé time is not. very far distant when India will become, like Ireland, a' per- manent entanglement of English politics, per- haps actually incapable of being resolved by constitutional reform. There is no longer any excuse for failure to understand for what the Indian National Congress stands."

div.head: Cholera Bulletin.
div.p: 177 deaths and 42 fresh cases are reported from Mecca.

div.head: E.T.C. Cable Steamer.
div.p: The C.S. "Electra" sailed from Suez on Thursday for Aden, atter having taken a sup- ply of cable.
The Pligrim Season.
The Egyptian pilgrimage has now come to | an end. The total number of Egyptians who} left this year for the Hedjaz is 15,858.
The Year's Almanaoks.
We have received a useful and attractive | calendar from Messrs. Waterlow Bros. and | Layton, which contains some usefa! postal in- | mation.
Strong Winde at Suez.
On Thursday morning a southerly gale was blowing at Suez, and the dredging in the roads | was temporarily suspended. Towards the after- noon the wind abated, and veered round to the | North.
The Holy Carpet.

The Mahmal and its escort left Jeddah on the 31st ult. for Mecca where they arrived on | the 7th inst. Dr. Suleiman Bey Hamada, the | Quarantine Board Delegate, who has been re- fused entrance to the Holy cities 'is still at Jeddah and will probably retarn here shortly.
A Vilage Tragedy.

Four girls of the village of Dimlig in the Menoufieh province have been suffocated while | sleeping together. Asphyxia was caused by the | room becoming filled with fumes from a chicken: | incubator which adjoined it. The girls were the grand-children of the omdeh of the village.
Notice to Advertisers,

The daily isaue of the "Egyptian Gazette" having been increased trom 6 to 8 pages, thus | necessitating the printing of the advertisement | pages at an earlier honr, alterations in adver- tisements cannot be guaranteed unless instruc: | tions are received during the afternoon of| the day before issue.
A Murderer Arrested.

A native of Beyrout, by name Ahmed Sha- tills, who, a few weeks ago, murdered one ot | his: relatives in that town and escaped to | Alexandria, has just been canght here by Hag | Alouan, a Turkish police officer from Beyrout, who came here for that purpose,. with the| assistance of the Alexandria police.

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE DANCE
div.p: The touch of khamsin these last few days has | affected most of us, and the dance at Ghezireh Palace on Thursday was somewhat listless in consequence, any people preferring to pass | the evening lazily in their chairs to taking | more active exercise. We were glad to notice several favonrites of last season back again in their respective places, notably Mrs. York with her two daughters, and Mr. and Mrs. Moreom who have also returned with the Misses Mor- com. Mrs. Devereux and her family had a} party of eight at dinner, Major Evans was | entertaining six guests, as were also Mr. Sander and Mrs. Hunting Howell, and Mrs de B Carey. Sir Jos Swan had a party of nine : Major and Mrs. Stevenson were dining with Mr. Rutherford, and other hosts and Lostesses of the evening included Mra. Miller, Mrs Grabam, Mr. MacNeil, Mr. and Mrs. Percival, Mr. H. Carter Wilson, Mrs. Lyons ete

Amongst those noticed during the evening were the Misses York, one in pale blue Empire gown with broad bands of painted satin, and the other in a frock of the same make expres- sed in fine lace weighted with large appliqués of soft coloured embroidery. The ceintere was draped bighat the back and fromeach shoulder hung long sash ends bearing other app! nS of embroidery. Mrs. Maclean's beautifnl y gown was very mach diamentée, the berthe being headed by a severe roulean of satin and finished at the front with a pink rose and knot of chiffon. Mrs. Molyneux was in a dress of fine lace over pale blue,the high waist- line outlined with black ; the Misses Morcom also wore lace frocks mounted ov Mrs. Stevenson was in black re! i handsome insertions of black and gold embroi dery, Princess liene Duleep Singh was wearin | a dainty frock of soft pink silk, long knottec ends of satin ribbon hanging from the waist to the bem of the skirt. Mrs. Hauting Howell | was in emerald green with a deep ceinture of | flowered satin Mrs. de B. Carey wore a hand some gown of black lace and jet ver white. | 'Miss Carey was in a soft shade of yellow, a narrow silver fringe outlining the folded draperies of the corsage. The Misses Coles were in pretty frocks of painted muslin, tiny bunches of roses tucked into the lace of the decollatage. Miss Schreiber was in grey silk, Miss Joseph was in white.

div.head: LORD CROMER ON FREE TRADE.
div.p: ANSWER TO CRITICISMS.
HIS POLICY IN EGYPT.
(Gazette's Special Service).
London, Saturday.

Lord Cromer as the guest of the Glasgow Unionist Free Trade Club last night made an excellent speech advocating a positive policy for Unionist Free' Traders. Replying to the criticism that he had advocated a Protectionist policy in Egypt he said that the fiscal policy of Egypt in recent years had been based on the Free Trade principles. The octroi duty had been abolished and the oustoms duty reduced to 4% on certain articles. The enstom duty did not offend against Free Trade What Free Traders opposed was im- position duties for protective purposes. Referr- ing to cotton duties he said that the excise duty was equivalent to the customs daty im- posed when the mills were established. Other- wise the local industry would have been protected. The duty was not levied in order to please Manchester but to prevent an artificial industry springing up and to safeguard the customs revenue in Egypt.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive gave yesterday'evening a fare- well banquet, at Abdeen Palace, to the Persian Consul General, Mirza Asghar Khan, on the occasion of his retirement. The banquet was attended by the Ministers, officials of the Maieh, and the officials of the Persian Consulate General.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: "IL BARBIERE DI SIVIGLIA. "

A welcome relief to the heavier class of opera which has characterised the Zizinia season up to the present was the production last evening of Rossini's ever green, and ever popular, " Barber of Seville". The performance from a musical point of view was an all | round success, but occasionally moments oc- ! curred when there was a distinct slackness.

Signorina Magrini Pinzi, who is not a stranger to Alexandrians, made a charming Xosina and sang the difficult masie allotted to the part with effect, scoring several well de- | served encores. Her performance however was i.creatly niarred by continual giggling and | chattering emanating from a quarter whence | such conduct would scarcely be expected, and | which met with unmistakable disapproval from | all parts of the theatre. Surely if certain in- | dividuals are nnable to appreciate high class music, they might at least have some consider- ation for the artistes who are engaged in executing very difficult tasks, and also for others in the audience who have paid for their entertainment. As we anticipated, Signor Nanzio Rapisardi sang his fumbers splendidly, bot | he lacks that tonch of comedy which is so linorder to present an adequate im- ynation of Figaro. Signor Carlo Walter ite at home as Basilio and gave an itinterpretation of the part, his fine vol ing heard to great advantage. Signor De Ry made a ver acceptable, althongh a trifle weak, Almaviva, and Signor Vittorio Trevisan was a sufficiently eccentric Dr. Bartolo. The minor characters were well sup- ported
The opera was followed by the ballet " La] notte di Valpurgis" which was exceedingly | well executed.

div.head: A FIGHT ON- THE BOURSE.
div.p: This morning judgment was given by the | Mixed Civil Court in a case arising put of a firbt on the Bourse. Mr. Roucho assaalted Mr. Mercinier, a remisier, in the "corbeille'"' of the stocks and shares. 'I'he latter brought an action against Mr. Roucho and asked LE. 500 as compensation for the blows and wounds he had received. This morning the Court awarded the plaintiff L.E 60 damages.

div.head: ASSOUAN NOTES.
div.p: THE NEW YEAR.
(From our owns CoRRESPONDENT.)
Assouan, 8th January.
The first week of the New Year has brought with it aconsiderableincreasein the temperature which to-day and yesterday mounted into the eighties, but the nights and mornings are deliciously cool.

The New Year was ushered in by a dance atthe Savoy which was a great success. The ball room was charmingly decorated with garlands of yeal flowers from the gardens which surround the hotel and the buffet provided by the management was much appreciated by dancers and onlookers alike.
A Picture Exhibition.

Picture lovers have had a treat this week in the exhibition of Mr. Ogilvie's water colour drawings, of which not a few have been paur- chased by visitors at the Cataract and Savoy Hotels who will carry them back to Europe to show their friends the charms of the Nile scenery. Mr. Ogilvie has lived for months at a time alone in the desert, and it has « yielded tohim as. it does to no hasty passer-by something of the secret of its mysterious fasci- nation and beauty. One of the most striking pictures he exhibited which was immediately sold is the "Evening Glow on the Ramasseum." It was painted at the season of high Nile and the rosy glow on the temple is reflected in a still pool left by the inundation. I am told that the"artist took four months to exeecute this work ashe was only able to paint for about five minutes each day when the temple is illuminated by the rays of the setting sun. Another very beautiful work, also an after- noon study, lit up with that wonderful light peculiar to Egypt that makes one think of "the light that never was on land or sea" re- presents the Temple of Dehr el Bahri with the mighty mountain wall behind it so illuminated that the crag-like forms of the rocks stand out distinctly, pink in the light and parple in the shadow while a faint haze veils the temple below. That Mr. Ogilvie can paint movement as well as silence is shown by his "Sandstorm in the Desert' phere you almost feel the wind that sways the two lonely palm trees and seea Bedouin straggling through the blinding sand with a heavily laden camel toiling behind him and while still farther off another figure, also pressing towards the goal of shelter and safety, emerges ghostly in the distance. The "Lonely , Palm Tree near Helouan" will be recognised by many who have stayed there and everyone who joves the desert will appreciate the faith- fal rendering of the landscape and the evening sky with its tender gradations of coloar. I hear Mr. Ogilvie intends giving an exhibition of his work at the Winter Palace at Luxor about the middle of this month so that people who missed seeing the pictures here and going down river will have another opportunity.
New Visitors.

Prince Waldemar of Prussia'is expected with his suite at theSavoy about the 20th of this month and the Dachess of Pless with her daughter the Countess von Hochberg and her son Count Wilhelm von Hochberg will arrive shortly

Among the distinguished visitors at the Sa- voy just now are Sir Barrington Simeon and Lady Simeon. Major Collins with Lady Evelyn Collins, the Countess Landberg, the German Military Attaché Ober Lieutenant Messner, Sir Stephen Mackensie, Mr. Shiard Samuel M. P.Mr Duveen the well known art expert of Lon- don and Mr. John Cooper.

Prince Lievin is still at the Cataract with his family and among other visitors at this ho- tel are Sir George Lambert,Sir Benjamin Scott, the Hon. Mr. Overend, Mr. Sharply Bainbridge and Mr. G. H. Faber M. P. The Rev. F. H. | Molesworth 'has come ap from Cairo with Miss Molesworth. Captain Lamb has returned to the | Cataract Hotel from Khartoum and Mr. and | Mrs. Adams Frost, Mr. and Mrs. Bates and | Mr. and Mrs Holbach have returned from Wa- | dy Halfa, Mr. Diacono, the popular manager of the Hamburg aud'Anglo American Nile Steams ship Co pany, is here from Cairo and wa entertaining some friends to dinner on the "Germania" last night This fine boat built last year held the blue ribbon of the Nile till the launching of the "Egypt" for she was new last year and everyone talked of her then as they are talking of the "Egypt" now. The Ham- barg and Anglo-American Nile Co. .well main- tain the high standard of excellence set by Messrs. Thos Cook and Sons as pioneers of the Nile traffic. Their steamer "Nubia" has com- menced running on the Second Cataract service and has just returned from. her first trip to Wady Halfa with a large member of passengers.

div.head: HELOUAN RACE MEETING
div.p: CLOSE RACING.

The first winter meeting of the Helouan Sporting Club was held yesterday afternoon in beautiful weather; indeed as regards the latter it is apparently sufficient for a race meet- ting at Helouan to be announced and the wea- ther at once is at its brightest, for on no occa- sion since the club was founded has a race been held on any thau the most perféct day. As was to be expected there was a much larger attendance than at the last meeting. The ma- jority of the visitors took advantage of the special train which left the Bab el Louk station, at 12.85 p.m. and the large dining hall of the Tewfik Palacs Hotel had very few vacant places | at lancheon time. The starts were for the most part good and there was no race in which the element of uncertainty was eliminated until the race was practically over. Thefourth race brought the greatest surprise when Hebab, a rank outsider,, succeeded in snatching the laurelg from Maintenon who had led the field from the start. There had been hard- ly any backing of the winner, with the re- sult that those who had been fortunate enough to lay their money On the horse pocketed P. T. 1206 on their stake of P. T. 20. The third and principal race of the day was splendidly run,the large field keeping well together, Khadrouf being hard pressed up to the very last. There were only three runners for the sixth and last race, but they acquitted themselves well and the result was uncertain until the ve- ry end. The Band of the King's Own Scottish Borderers performed at intervals during the af- ternoon and substantial tea was served in the rustic enclosure adjoining the beautiful gardens of the Tewfik Palace Hotel. The number board which has been erected opposite the grand stand is a very great improvement.
(From our Lapy CorresponpeEnt.)

Alter the trying weather of the last few days the clear fresh air of Helouan yesterday after- noon was as grateful as a sea breeze and those who attended the race meeting returned to Cairo all the better, if sleepier, for their outing. It was an exceedingly pleasant meeting indep- endently of the racing, for many people from Cairo were present, and the surroundings were all of the cheeriest. One lady, a stranger to the ground, was heard to remark that the palm branch roofs of the stands etc. made her feel 'as primitive as Robinson Crusoe; and indeed much of the success of these meetings is due to the delightfully 'al fresco' nature of the proceedings.

Many people from Cairo travelled down to Helouan by the special train which land- ed them in time -to enjoy an excellent lunch; either at- the Tewfik Palace Hotel or further afieki ; and there was quite a goodly number in their places to see the first race ran. Others arrived soon after, and by 3.80 there was quite a numerous assembly of the rank ard fashion in the stand, and in the paddock between the races. Mrs. Irene Harvey brought « party of those who had been lunching with her:—Major and Mrs. Stevenson, Mrs. de Bilinski with Miss and Mr. A. de Bilinski, and Mra Hewlett, Mrs. and Miss Carey with Princesse Irene, Mr. Grey, and Mr. de Rentian were present : Major and Mrs. Robertson Eustace were also with friends. Mrs. and Miss Sehorgler Ross, Coles Pasha with his niece, Mrs. Eshiels and Miss Frost, Captain and Mrs. Morgan, Mr. and Miss Wilson, Captain Darell, Captain Adams, Messrs P. Stout, R. Marsham, Goodchild and Pooley, were among those who journeyed ont from Cairo, while among those staying in Helonan | forthe moment were Miss Johnstone, Mrs. Merkt, Dr and Miss Hobson, Mr. Bolland and Mr. Tomlinson.

The last race was ron just as the sun was | setting: it disappeared below the horizon before | the special left the station and the homeward journey back to Cairo was passed watching the glorious afterglow illuminating the scene against. which the figures on the river side became as duaky silhouettes.

div.head: MR. LAMPLOUGH'S PICTURE EXHIBITION.
div.p: Mr. A. 0. Lamplough's exhibition of paint- ings which is being held at the Hotel d'An- gleterre is deservedly attracting the attention of all lovers of the art in Cairo. Mr. Winston Charchill accompanied General Bullock on a long visit of inspection to the studio on Wed- nesday afternoon, and among the numerous other enthusiasts who have availed themselves of this opportunity of seeing Mr. Lamplough's work this week are ; Sir William and Lady | Willcocks, Mr. Alexander Smirnow, Russian | Minister, Lady Blomfield, Count a.d Countess Bernstorff, Captain Duffus, Dr. Alexander Prior, Captain Rothwell, Judge Royle, M, Alexis de Xoievodsky, Secretary to the Di- plomatic Agency of Russia, the Revd. B. Armitage, Mr. and Mrs. Amalote. and M Poget. We onderstand that the present ex- hibition is to close on the 18th inst., Mr, Lamplough having many schemes of work in hand for the time that he is to remain in the country, one of which is to be the painting of a series of the fast disappearing beauty spots of Cairo and its sorroundings within a radius of ten miles. This series. painted by such a master hand as that of Mr. Lamplough, will be of great and lasting iuterest, and we only regret that it was not undertaken sooaer be- fore so many of the picturesque corners of the old town had already disappeared. However, there still remains an abudance of spots which the march of the newer generation 'has left un- touched, and the artist by immortalizing them with his brash may be assuted of the gratitude of lovers of this old world. beauty. The pictures which are at present on view are all charm- ing and it is Bonga any particular one out for special mention. However, if any choice is to be made, it must be accorded to one in which the Citadel appears in the mists of evening. The colouring is delightfal and the tone is perfect ; the mist clad palms ap- pear to fade away in the growing dusk even as one studies the picture, and the effect pro- duced is not one to be easily forgotten. A corner of old Cairo js also a very perfect piece of work, and an exceedingly fine painting of the desert, free from habitations. of any kind, is also'on view. Every picture contains an atmosphere of its own. and Mr. Lamplough has caught the beauty of the mists of an Eastern evening, in a manner which in our opinion bas seldom or nevet been equalled.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Duke of Madrid and party arrive by the "Schleswig."
Mr. P.E.I. Hemalryk, the Consul for Japan at Liverpool. willarrive on Monday by the "Schleswig."

Marquis Salvago Raggi, Governor of | Erithrea, embarked at Ismailia yesterday on board the N.D.L. steamer "Kleist," which left Suez in the afternoon for Aden, where he will embark on the' Florio Rubattino steamer "Flovio Gioia" for Massawab.
Mr.and Mrs Elisha Miller, who have been up the Nile on their dahabeah tor a month, left by the "Heliopolis" on Thursday for Marseilles and will spend the remainder of the winter at Nice.

Amongst the latest arrivals at the Grand Continental Hotel we note Count and Countess de Branicki, Count Bethune, Count de Franoqueville, Mr. de la Barriére, Count Enrico Sapelli di Capriglio, Comm., Aragio Lo- renzi, Sir G.8. Robertson, Col. von Rosza.

div.head: A RADICAL M-P. IN EGYPT.
div.p: A striking proof of the manner in which the violence of Mustapha Pasha Kamel's policy has alienated him from the sympathy of the Radicals in Parliament is to be seen by the silence with which the "Egyptian Standard" treats Dr. Rutherford, M.P. A year ago Mr. Robertson, M.P. and Dr. Ratherford were lauded to the skies by Kamel, who apparently believed that all the Radicals in the House of Commons, who displayed any interest in Egypt, were bis hamble followers. Bat now that Kamel has been entirely thrown over by all ~ sensible people in Egypt, he retaliates by re- fraining from mentioning their names. The silence of the "Standard" regarding Dr. Ruther- ford's visit is astonishing ! Can it be that this Radical Member of Parliament 'is so obtuse as not to have recognised Kamel's transcendent genios and his predominant influence in this country 1 That were dulness indeed.

Dr. Rutherford had a very busy day on Thursday. He visited the Advisers to the Ministries of Public Works, Justice & Pinance, and Saad Pasha Zaghloul with the last named of whom he spent a considerable time. On ths previous day he had an interview with Dr. Graham by whom he was introduced to Dr. Keating who showed him over the Kaar el Aini Hospital.On Tharsday evening he attend- ed a small dinner given in his honour by Sheik Ali Bey Yussef.

div.head: THE LEBANON MUTASARRIF.
div.p: News comes from the Lebanon that the Administrative Council has decided to increase the salary of the Mutasarrif, who received LT. 2°0 per month, to L.T. 8240 per annum. Forty years ago the Governor General of the Lebanon received L.T. 300 per month ; but at that time the revenoe of the country was insuf- ficient to cover all the Mutasarrifiat expenses, Rustam Pasha, the third Mutasarrif, who rendered great services to both the Tarkish Government and the Lebanon, had reduced the Matasarrifiat officials, not excepting his own salary, and since then the annual financial aid given by the Sultan has been withheld. In view of the fact that the officials' salaries are very smallin comparison with the dearnest of the living, Youssef Franco Pasha has imposed fresh taxes on the Lebanese, and the Mutasarri- fiat salaries including, his own, were increased. The Lebanese, as we hear, are not dissatisfied with the new arrangements.

div.head:
GERMANY'S PARLIAMENT.
REJECTION OF UNIVERSAL SUFFRAGE.

div.p: The Chamber has rejected a Liberal proposal for the establishment of direct universal suf- frage. Prince von Buelow opposed the proposal. (Havas)

The Abyssinia affair is regarded seriously here. The papers are confident that Menelik will take action to prevent a recurrence of the incident. It is pointed out that the Italian position is strong in view of the treaty be- tween Great Britain, France, and Italy gua- ranteeing matual co-operation in the safeguard- ing of all interests in Ethiopia. Moreover, there is a sufficient Italian naval force on the African coasts. Signor Carletti, the Governor of Benadir, who is at present on furlough will return immediately. (Reuter)
Signor Tittoni will be interpellated in the Champer of Deputies on the subject of the Abyssinian incident.
Deputi Chiesi, in the course of an interview, said that he considered the incident an act of aggression on the part of Menelik and feared that Italy would have to endure a painful retreat.
The press here continues confident that Menelik was not concerned in the raid.
Signor Carletti in an interview repndiated the idea that Benadir was endangered. The incident, he said, must not be exaggerated.
Apprehension is éxpréssed for the fate of Captains Bongiovanni and Molinari, news re- garding whom is lacking. (Reuter)
Deputy Lucifero will question the Govern- ment op the incursion of the Abyssinians at Laugh. (Havas)

Lord Cromer, addressing the Unionist Free Trade Club at Glasgow, said that be preferred to adhere to the. antiquated fiscal faith of proved merit to rusting blindfold into un- known radical. changes. He denied thathe was | a protectionist in Egypt. The fiscal policy of Egypt of late years had been the base of his free trade principles. The customs dues were levied for revenue, not protective parposes. He deprecated strongly old age pensions, which, he said, would 'eradicate self-help which was the mainstay of our national character, and would "oblige the thrifty to support the unthirifty. (Reuter)
El Mokri, sent by the Sultan of Morucco, has arrived to negotiate fora loan. (Havas)
General Drude bas arrived at Marseilles. ( Havas)
The newspapers report serious disaffection amongst the native troops at Tonking. ( Heuter)
The National. Bank has lowered the Bank raté to 7 7%. ( Havas)
Test Match. Australia 279 runs for 9 wickets. Macartney made 75 runs ( Reuter)

div.head: REVERIE D'EGYPTE
div.p: I listen to many sounds : I see many things: The hum of purple and gold-winged insacts, shadows aslant the sand and the colonr.that flies from the heart of a flower... The. per- fume. that steals upon one... Riot, of rose- tipped flecks deepening the rose of a sky which has the rose that shimmers on .the scales of the mackerel fish; rose inlaid with patches of turquoise... The laughter of youth and the gleaming light on the wings of the swallows as they flash across the Nile...

I see the palm-trees silhouetted through ithe golden air and the silvery shafts: of the | moon. I hear the lilt of the wind and the twitter of sleepy birds. I seem: to feel an embrace ; it appears to me and a lump rises in my throat as I try to, keep back the scalding tears.

..A lone: bird waits in her empty nest close in the harbouring reeds. Stars which hang low watch over pitiful graves, sad, lonely graves which stand bare and forgotten in this land of strangers. The warm Southern pulse that makes everything weep, or exalt in strange fierce ecstasy...
I dream, and I call these sights and these sounds and these impressions, the voice of my soul, my inper sight.
The mystery of this land fascinates me with a fascination which is tinged. with Wehmut. I gaze with hot eyes through unshed tears... The great pity of the land of Egypt.
A hopeless memory crowds my brain : Echoes haunt me night and day, while sha- dows drift where there is nothing.

A voice calls to me to come away, away. It: whispers that here there is no joy, that the joy of life is dead for me, that for me]. there is no gladness and no glory in Egypt atid that although the sun blazes overhead for me also, there is nothing left for my portion but grey. shadows and> faint, intan- gible dreams, vague dreams, dim as the flight of birds mirrored at night in the umber waters of the Nile, dreams which pale and fade beyond remembrance until they are lost in the night.

What do I seek here in the desert, what pleasure, what joie de vivre, what blessed oblivion of life? Isit'release from the clang and clamour of imperial cities, is it avoidance of harassing folk, is it the peace of solitude, the deep quiet of complete isolation, or is it pride which draws me apart and do | here masquerade, a lonely mummer, as one who is above her fellow-men and women? In the old days the desert beyond the Nile was flecked with the huts of the solitary cenobites. And am I like those recluses of days gone by, wasting the golden hours of life in the Nirvana of idle contemplation, so that my Ego grows to be a monstrous, poisonous weed? And if this be so will not the time come when every vein in my body will yearn with the parched thirst of the salt desert-sand for the warm, red blood of men and women who live in sweet com munion with their fellow-beings

Out there where the sky stoops to kiss the line of the horizon by phantom gradations of misty grey and the sheen of moonlight, I seem to seea vision. Is it but the mirage of the desert? Not indeed of the Egyptian desert bat of that weary waste which is my despair- ing, solitarysoul Isita mirage of the mind? Yet, while I hesitate and wonder, my eyes strain passionately t6 take the vision in, to drink it up. Is it not some loved, ideal crea- tion of my. own, a pleasant land which I shall never see otherwise than in fevered dreams, | until the golden, wondrous hours when infinite dreams come true.

Amidst the troubled haze down by the river- bank, I sometimes fadcy that I see a form waiting for me by the side of. boat, sweet, | silent. Then fear seizes upon me—or is it | wanton hope. There is an intuition of loss which deepens into despair and in utter lonelinesas I sink to deeper dreams.

...I know a laughing brook that rans and ledps far down a mountain side and which then, like a truant, or a frightened child, pauses, and creeps thiough a forest where no birds sing, where no'tender throat strains out in softest music. It is a desolate place, an unclaimed land, but all its virgin silence speaks to me: itis the realm, where a pure, sweet love—a love far sweeter, far greater far more overpowering than that of any man, will, I know, I feel, be discovered.
My heart has become a silent place. Oh ! if I could but wake from my lethargy, awake to

hear the voice of music, or Yen see form grief, somesorrowful) shape, 'with TA and deep, dear, tired eyes. Orelse, alas, that for which Ido so yearn, if 1 might only feel some simple happiness, wide-eyed as are the innocent marguerites.

...I know a wood where night has fallen 3 now, amidst the .poplars, larches, sycamores, chestnut-trees and oaks and beeches, a wood, where the bandit owls go hooting through the | branches and under-brash. 'These robbers are never still, They wake and distarb the bridal birds in their wedding-nests in the cruellest fashion. They shout and call: "Who's Who'. Who's Who. . 0. . 0 & o."laughing viciously, and making the timidhearts of little birds beat. with frightened. throbs} As if the little, cosy birds could answer their persistent query. ''Who's.Who?" indeed. , indeed.
And yet with frightened bravado, with the fear that dares, the tits and linnets and the gamin blackbirds answer, and then try to sleep | again.

The wood is dark now, very dark for it is night-time there and itis very cold. Not even a firefly nor one lone glow-worm sheds its little light across the ink-black paths. All the tiny things that are warm ir fur or feather are fast asleep, dreaming, till one of them, an early ri- ser shall proclaim the dawn.

I dreamed that I was' waiting in a lonely garden, one of God's acres, where unclaimed children sometimes find their way to rest and sleep An All-Souls' twilight brooded over the lovely place at the setting of the sun. | waited expectantly, swayed now by hope and now by fear...

I gazed down the flower-bordered walks and tiny mounds where each small cross kept vigil above the little jewel that was laid beneath. I looked where rose-garlanded bowers overarched the ways, and beyond, where the grussipath winds towards the wicket gate. I peered about, starting at every sound, to see if a little child would come that way, I strained my eyes with that tense eagerness which only childless wo- men know, to see if some little form might ap- pear along the path, under the arches garlan- ded with roses, some little child whom I should know again.

Oh ! I waited long, very long. The sun went down beyond the hawthorn trees and a shy, young moon peeped over the branches. And children came But there was not among them the child I sought. Listlessly they came along as though they too had been waiting and look- ing and had not found, and were tired as I was, tired of the world of men. The white roses drooped to kiss their golden curls as they pas- sed under the arches and behind them in the grass I saw wany flowers, which were not there before, marking their frail footsteps. But the golden child whom the red roses should embow- | wer, the awaited infant for whom the trumpet | lilies should blow their notes of glad proclaim, the baby king for whom every flower in that royal garden should toss its head in gladdest welcome. . . "It never came." And I a childless woman, with the sadness greater than that of Rachel mourving tor her Jost ones, I who had never even had the sweet despair of loss, stoop- ed down again and again and peered in the. the wistful young faces, that were so full of wonder, seeking with Oh! such longing for so- me tender recognition. And again and again I laid my hand gently on the golden carls and bade the child go on its way, alone, trom me alone. My voice choked with sudden tears "O God!" I cried "I want my own, Will it} never come to me ?"

Then presently another child came wander- ing by. I seemed to know its form. I seemed to have seen before—when, where, in what dim and forgotten period of delight !—the violet pools beneath the golden curls, below the soft white forehead, the violet pools which were its eyes, in which so many times my glad face had mirrored itself. And the mouth tdo seemed one that once I had kissed many many timés, 4 | pouting, red mouth that seemed made by God's own hands sv that it should say Motherin tones of unspeakable sweetness, And the banda | that seemed to grope for something iound } which the tiny fingers might coil, the little | bands which every fragrant night air kissed as it went sighing past, they looked to me like hands which had clasped my neck and sought my bosom. .. . And I called out in an agony of suspense: "Hasten, darling, Come to me."
But it did not seem to hear and pansed, disregarding me, to gather dewy flowers. .Then, with patience all spent, I darted forward and snatched it to my side.

And then nothing more was said between us two. What need of words was there between that child and me? We held each other heart to heart, so close, so tight, so warm. It seemed to melt into my bosom. It became part of ie. I enveloped it and I was warm with love.

.... And then . . and then I awoke, cold, cold, chilled to the bone by the fierce air of the nightly desert. Miles and miles of infinite sand, sterile, salt, dead stretched out before me, in eniblem of my utter desolation. . . A lonesome pariah dog, a gauat figure far 'away, was howling its hunger to the moon.
Helouan, January 8th, 1907.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the sex opinion pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permitwithin cortainnecesssry limite— discussion.
CAIRO POST ORFICE.
To Th Editor or THe 'Eayprian Gazerre."

Sir—In reference to the letter of "A Saffer- er" in today's issue on the delays at the parcel post: department of-the @: P10. at'Caito, I must say that asa eomparativestranger in this country, | -bave- found -the postal arrangements in Egypt exeellent and.the-officials ivvariably polite. I had only been in Cairo, three-weeks and had my letters. addressed to the Poste Restante-until 1 had » permanent address. As soon as Iwas. settled L-notified-the postmaster of my new permanent address. About two days afterwards Lhappenedto.meet the clerk who. was inthe habit of delivering me my. mails at the Poste Restante. Ishad. only seen him about half a dozen times when be saluted me, addressed me by name, and gaid thet in future your letters will always be delivered, at your new address. Thia little episode speaks for its- self and certainly goes far to prove that the @ P.O. at Cairo is not in the dark ages as "A Sufferer' suggest.
Truly Yours Nemo.
Alexandria, 10th January.

div.head: EGYPTIAN. POLITICS.
div.p: To THE Editor of THE "EaypTiaN GAZETTE."

Sir,—It is, somemhat.astenishing when one comes seriqusly to think of itthat so many ritics take the view.they do when dealing with affairs of. Egypt—surposing inasmoch as it seems to, be. forgotten, by them. that certain Egyptians who, have, come prominently forward of late and who have time.and. again declared their principles to be the moat moderate ones of peaceful advance are only acting as patriotic representatives of any nation might be expect- ed to act.. There.are rapid .triflers .with grave issues who. declare. with the giry persiflage which is.to,be looked,for from surface reayoners that moderates are,oo nse. This argument comes from people who sppareptly look upon politics simply asa show and who are 809 disappointed it there is no wild declamation and no tub thumping that they are disposed to condemn in toto any. policy which does not include these two,cardinal.elements of hysterical display.

The grand mistake these censors make is to expect from grave politicians such as our visitors of last summer, the same exhibition of useless if agile antics which are in the program- me of self seeking orators whose device is "Paisons du bruit." Egypt does pot require agitation, butit may well be that wise and temperate criticism of its affairs, by its own peblic men. will act asa tonic end fillip to further adyance. Moreover {wo apparently but not really irreconcilable things might come in time to complete and, harmonioas. fusion if such prudent coansellors as these were called toa Council of the Empire savh as we have not at | present, but which might be borrowed in name though not in fact from Petersbug.

But whether this is a realisable asset of future progress or not, certain it is that those Englishmen. who takes keen interest is foreign polities — and unfortunately for England these are few—I would if they knew the facts be the first to applaud the actions of the moderates, and it is a thoasand pities that sach knowledge of the facts is retarded bythe discourteous and even wrong headed attempt to herald any new 80 called party as a rival and to knowingly sod wilfully lconfuse the whole issue by leading the nn- | sophisticated Englishman to believe that the | reformers to whom I refer are ovly one group | | among many and that intransigeance here as | elsewhere is the tramp card.

Emphatically this i6 not so. The game is | sans a tout i it comes to that, though it is not a game, but merely a whole hearted attempt to meet apathy by correct means, and to take a vivid interest in the destinies of race and not a land Loyal co-workers with England, their labours should provoke en- | thusiasm They are leading public opinion in | a manner which will certamly redound to | the credit of the Empire and its welfare. Both irresponsible mountebanks who take out of the gaiety of their hearts in frivolous dispa- ragement of Egyptian parties, imagine for one moment that Egypt cannot produce public men of weight and learning, men whose counsels are worthy to be listened to and set down ? If they do they are fpndamentally at fault. "Egypt has its thinkers as well as its workers and to cast ridicule on those men who come.,forward,with valuable messages, is to invite the recoil of sach misplaced contempt.

One may trust fortunately that the short sighted and ill-informed criticisms indicated have so far done bat little harm. London knew how to appraise at. its right and high valoe the work of these avant couriers of an already accomplished better understanding. | But before all things the error should never be | repeated. of confusing these, emissaries and | their policy with the rowdy fulminations of | a crowd of assertive. notoriety, mongers, whose | motives are, to say theleast,absolutely, different in charadter.
I am, Sir, Yours, etc.
A London Radical. London, January. 1.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Cette semaine encore, avec la f¥te de Noél Orthodoxe et l'anniversaire de l'av¢nement au trone de 8.A. le Khédive, nous n'avons eu que trois séances, dont les deux premiéres faibles et indécises et la derniére, celle d'au- jourd'hui, ferme et en hausse.

Le principal mobile de cette allure contra dictoire a été la baisse du coton durant les premiers jours, snivie d'une reprise apprécia- ble. On ne doit pas étre sorpris de cette in- finence considérable exercée par la tenue des contrats sur la corbeille de nos valeurs: la plupart de nos spéculateurs sont engagés simultanément dans les deux ebranches et lorsqu'ils subissent des pertes en cotous ils sont obligés de liquider leurs porteleuilles titres pour payer leurs différences, C'est ce qui est atrivé ces jours derniers ; mais les cotons s'étant ressaisis, les ventes de ce chef ont par le fait' m@me cessé de peser sur Jes cours.

Ce n'est pas d'ailleurs le seul élément de hausse qu'on mette en avant. La semaine a été remplie de nouvelles tant locales que de I'étran- ger favorables 4 un relévement. Dans ces con ditions et aprés un coup d'wil jeté sur la cote en somme stationnaire on se demande ce qu'tl serait atrivé si les informations optimistes n'avaient pas contribué 4 soutenir les prix.

C'est d'abord le taux officiel de la Banque de France qui esttombé de4 4 3 1/2 7%, me sure quin'a pu étre motivée que par une dé- tente sensible de la tension monétaire et qui | est un signe avant-courear d'une réduction | proportionnelle du taux dansiles autres pays. | En faveur dela huusse on fait également va- | loir que dans la premi¢re quinzaine de janvier les Gouvernements paient les coupons de leurs emprunts et que c'eat aussi l'époque de la distribution des dividendes pour un grand nombre de sociétés, L'or retenu ou drainé dans ce but*va done rentrer en circulation et faciliter ainsi les transactions.

Depuis quelques jours il parviendrait - aussi de |'étranger des ordres d'achet importants et suivis, qui n ont pas peu contribué au raffer- missement actuel en dépit de l'époque defavo- rable et de notre situation de place encore ébraniée. L'arrét de la baisse et la demande étrangére constatée sur bon nombre de nos titres de premier ordre tendent » démontrer que si la spéculation ne retombe pas dans ses exeds anterieurs on est en droit d'escompter pour ces valeurs sinon de la bausse, du moins une consolidation des prix, de nature 4 rame- ner sur le tapis la question du rétablissement du marché terme.

Déja. les banqnes locales, suivant en cela l'exemple des . marchés europrens, ont réduit leur taux d'intérét de 9 4 & 0/0, et si Ja dimi- nution du taux d'escompte s'accentue en Eu- rope, elles seront sans doute amenées a le re duire encore. C'est d'ailleurs indispensable pour déterminer un mouvement de hausse. Ii suffit pour s'en convaincre de sé reporter au rendement de nos valeurs. En prenant une we- yenne de 3 4 4 0/0 entre celles qui donnent des coupons avantageux et celles qui n'en donnent que peu ou pas, on voit que lacquéreur de titres, obligé de payer 4 son banyuier 80/0, se trouve en perte de 4 0/0 au bout de l'année. Il est vrai que !'acbeteureseompte une plus-value, mais aprés une crise financitre comme celle de 1906-1907, il voudra une base plus solide pour établir ses prévisions. C'est pour cela qu'il est difficile de prévoir des mouvements de hausse tres accentués tant que le taux local dintérét est & un niveau si élevé, d'autant plus quill ne mangue pasici de placements plus rémunéra- teurs A le fois et plus sfirs

"Un autre obstacle qui est d'ailleurs sur Je point de disparattre, motivé qu'il était par la | préocca pation des banques de présenter en fin | d'exercice un bilan aussi pea chargé que pos sible d'engagements, ce sont les difficultés oppo- | sées par les établissements de erédit pour augmenter ou méme ouvrir de nouveaux comp tes. La date de la présentation des bilans étant passée, il est probable que la s¢yerité sur ce point sera un peu relachée. Jusqu'a présent les banques en général ne consentent pas de nouvelles avances sur titres, mais il faut espé rer qu'aprés la négociation de la récolte co tonniére quitegehe-a sa fin, elles ne voudront | pas laisser improductifs les capitaux q sont immobilisés et les emploieront, en parte du moins, 4 des avances de ce genre.

On a déja dit que je numéraire ne fai pas défaut ;. ce qni semble le démontrer c'est | que l'importation d'or a cessé depui que rope temps et que la. quantité demandée a TE roy : heh 4 Lot . l } dans ce dessein a é¢te inieneur a Cee CES | années précédentes.

Pour en revenir 4 notre marché, il ta gnere changé dans l'ensemble. La plupart des va leurs y sont offertes sans trouver s.r place de contre partie. Heureusement I' Eurupe absorbe une bonne part des paquets jetés dan beille. Ainsi la séance de ce matin a é quée tout particuliérement parie mouy ement | des arbitragistes qui rachétent sur piace 4 des | 1 cours plus bas.ce.qu ila ont d'abord en soin de vendre au Steck Exchange et A Paris, ot les | valeurs égvptiennes ont une meilleure tenue.
A signaler parmi les titres échangés la | National Bank, la Daira, l' Alexandria W ater, l'Abookir, la Land Bank, les actions et obliga: tions Crédit Foucier, la Banque d'Athénes et I' Unifiée.

L'Obligation Crédit Foncier, qui était tom- bée dernitrement jusqu'au prix inoui de 270 sous le poids des offres et réalisations de | 'épargne aux abois, qui n'avait pas d'antre titre immédiatement négociable, a repris cette semaine dés que les ventes ont cessé, pour faire place 4 une demande active et suivie. Et c'est toujours |'épargne qui rachéte

Sur une soixantaine de valeurs inscrites & la cote Officielle de la Bourre d' Alexa drie 15 sont en hanase et 19 en beisse Toutes les autres demenrent stationnaires aux cours an- térieurs, La plopart d'aillears, m@me parmi

celles dont les prix'ont varié, n'ont donné lien A aucune traysaction, et s'il n'y avait pas | la séance de ce matin pour rompre cette déso- lante monotonie on pourrait considérer la semaine comme absolument nvlle. A ce sujet il n'est' pas sans intérét de consulter la cote de la Bourse du Caire ot les trois quarts des titres sont accompagnés de la mention : nomi- nal. I] evest 4 peu prés de mémeici.

Dans ces conditions on ne sera pas surpris de constater que les finctuations u'ont pas d'ampleur ni de-.signification. Les plus impor- tuntes sont une hansse de 6 francs sur J'obli- gation ancienne Crédit Foncier contre une aisse de 4 francs sur les Sucreries et de 1 4 sur la part de fondateur Comptoir. A signaler encore 1/8 de hausse en National Bank, Ram- leh et Daira, et 1/8 de baisse en Building Lands, Les autres variations sont insignifiantes.

Le taux privé d'escompte baisse en An- gleterre de 50/0 & 4 5/8, pendant que la reé- serve de la Banque progresse de 35 5/8 » 48 1/8 0/0; ce qui, si les dép@ches sont exactes, donnerait une respectable augmentation en hnit jours de 13 0/0 environ. Quantaux va- leurs égyptiennes, leurs cours sont loin d'ex- pliquer le monvement qu'on prétend s'étre éta- bli entre Londres et ici. L'Agricole et la Na- tional Bank restent sans chancement ; seules la Delta Light et la Daira avancent de 1/8. Ladifféreuce des cours étant au-dessous de la proportion normale, on se demande quel avantagelexceptionnel peuvent avoir les arbi- tragiates qui achétent ici 'pour revendre a Londres.
A' Paris on constate une légére am/lioration des cours pour l'action Crédit Foncier, la Land Bank et la Banque d'Athénes qui gagnent res- pectivement 1 et 2 francs.

Comme tendance, on ne peut rien dire en- core sinon que nous allons rentrer dans une période annuelle de reprise, mais il serait, peas tre téméraire des''emballer cette année-ci apres les dures lecons de l'an dernier. Il serait en outre bon de moutrer 4)'Europe mise en dé- fiance que la spéculation s'est un peu calmée.

Dans une rénnion tenue le 5 Janvier, 1908, « Alexandrie au Siége de |'Association des Courtiers en Valenra et sur l'initiative du Comité de la dite Association, il a été décidé de fonder une Association de défense des inté- réts des actionnaires égyptiens, sur les bases suivantes: A) L'Association éntreprend avant tout nne w@uvre de conservation et de préser- vation de la fortune publique. B) Les membres de Association doivent étre établis dans le pays, C) Lorsque le Comité décidera d'exer- cer une action en justice, cette action sera inteutée au nom des intéressés eux-mémes et ceux-ci devront s'engager & verser une provision dont le taux sera fix- par le Comité. Dans ces limites, voici le programme sommaire de I' Asso- ciation et de son Comité: 1° Etudier la situation des Sociétés Anonymes Egyptiennes et é¢tran- véres dont les titres sont' l'objet de tran- sactions auk Bourses d'Alexandrie et du Caire. 2° Provoquer des explications amiables des Conseils d' Administration de ces bociétés. 3° Instituer on bureau d'études ob tous les ren- seignements utiles & connaitre concernant Jes sociétés nouvelles et anciennes seront réunis. 4° Former un Conseil de Contentieux. 5° Ac- cueillir les plaintes motivées des actionnaires adhérents et leur apporter, le cas échéant et apres enquéte compléte, un coycours matériel et moral; dans ce but, provoquer des réunions officieuses des actionnaires et porter, sil ya lieu, leurs décisions reconnues légitimes de- varit des Assemblées légalement convoquées et an besoin devant les juridictions compétentes égyptient es on etrangeres. Il est entendu que le Comité restera maitre d'étendre son actiou daiis les limites de la déferise des actionnaires,

div.head: LLOYD AUTRICHIEN
div.p: L'Agence generale du Lloyd Autrichien nons communique qu'etant debordee par les demandes de subdivision de connaissements elle se voit obligee a partir du 13 courant de taxer de 50 centimes chaque ordre de livraison supplementarie.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton

Le marché a été mouvementé cette huitaine. On a attribué aux menaces-d'one gréve par les fileurs A bagues da Lancashire le violent récul qui a caractérisé le debut de la semaine. Les cours, qui avaient fiéchi un instant jasqu'al 5/8, ont cependant repris 13/16 de talari, sans que le conflit entre patrons et ouvriers fit encore résolu. Liavance sur vendredi dernier est ainsi de 1/4 de tallari.

Les causes de ces importantes fluctuations sont presque exclusivement spéculatives ; bien qu'il soit juste de noter' que le rapport du Census bureau, évaldant la quantité égrenée a 9.955.000 contre 11.750. 944 balles l'année der- niére, a puissamment contribué aa. raffer- missement des cours de ce soir.

Cette estimation est, en effet, trés favorable pour nos cotons, puisqi'elle ie laisse prévoir, pour Ja campagne americaine' actuelle, qu'une récolte de 1.750.000 au maximum contre 13.500.000 l'année deraiére.

Certains spéculateurs profitérent de l'embar- ras dans fequel se trouvait momentanément une des principales agences de notre ville, pour impressionner la place par des nouvelles alarmantes qui provoguérent une forte baisse mercredi dans la matinée. Liagence ayant eu soin de liquider ses positions avant d'annoncer la cessation de sea paiements, |'effet que nos manipulatenrs espéraient obtenir de leurs ma- noeuvres nese Vérifia beureusement pas. Par coutre, un mouvement ascensionnel se dessina dans |'aprés-midi, mouvement qui ne s'est plus arrété depuis, au grand d: sespoir des baissiers. On nous informe aujourd'hui que |'agence en question reprendra demain ses paiements, qu'elle n'avait interrompue que pour des rai- sons tout 4-fait imprévues.

Quant aux derniers renseignements eoncer- nant les menaces d'une gréve,. qui attemdrait tout particuli@rement les cotous égyptiens, nous dirons, sur la foi de certainds dépéches privées, qae ceux qui se tiennent dans les coulisses savent parfaitement que les bases, sur lesquelles le conflit ouvrier se trouvera réglé sont pour ainsi dire déja arrétées.

L'activité a été grande pendant la semaine. Les positions 4 la havsse ont passé en des mains plus sfires et le marché s'est réssnisi grace surtout a l'intervention du commerce qui a opéré un grand nombre d'achats.
Le Janvier ne donne plus lieu qu's des at- faires occasionnelles, le mois en question étant passé presque complétement entré les mains de exportation 4 l'heure qu'il est.
Le Mars, qui est devenu par suite-le mois favori des gros faiseurs, cléture a 18 7/16 contre 18 3/16 la semaine derniére.
La spéculation tend ase porter de-plas en plas vers les échéanceséloignéeset le Novetibre a été largement traité pour cloturer 4/8 11/16 soit en ayance de 1/2 tallari sur Vendredi dernier.

Les exportations, qui ont dépassé les pro- nostics les plus optimistes, atteignent eette seinaine 36.758 contre 33.718 balles. l'année dernitre pour la méme période. Les pré visions | pour la semaine prochaine sont satisfaleantes. i ll est intéressant de noter que les arrivagés sont, par contre, de 30,000 cantars .inférieurs & ceux de l'année derniere durant la méme se- | maine et que notre stock 4 Minet-el-Bassal est également en dimination de 41,000° caritats.

Liverpool n'a pas été favorable aux cotors égyptiens sous le rapport des prix qui ont baissé de 10 & 12 points pourles différentes échéances et de 6/64 pour le Spot. Quant auz | ventes du disponible, elles t'atteignent en | moyenne que 200 balles par jour.
Une certaine préssion s'ext fait sentir pour | vendre nos cotons sar cé mafehé, ot les prix | sont irréguliers, mais les bonnes qualités ont | moins de tendance a baisser que les basses. qua- i lités
En ce qui concerne les filés, les prix ont reculé en sympathie avec ceux du coton, mats le volume des transactions a ¢t4 tris petit.

Les américains n'ont pas eu beancoup d'em train et sous le rapport des prix le marehéw été faible; le Middling cléture a 6.12; et-lew | {aturs s'inscrivent 45.69 pourle févrief-mats et & 5,71 le juin-juillet, soit en perte de deux. points.

Le marché de Minet-el-Bassal n'a pas été trés satisfaisant. Les détentenrs actuels, qui sont des négociants indigénes, sont souvent obligés de vendre, au prix de nombreuses con- cessions,' lear marchandise afin de payer le solde df an fellah. Il est vraiment regrettable que les Banques locales ne soient pas en mesure de consentir des avancée' sir les cotons afin den maintenir les prix.
La cote du Spot nous montre une baibsd qui contraste 'étrangement avec la hausse des contrats. Le Brown subit une réaction sensible, tandis que la Haute-Egypte et Fayoum-ne baissent que légérement.
L' Abbassi reste sans changement; par contre, le Joannovich baisse d'an demi-tallari Je fully: good fair etun quart les -qualités fines. Le Nubari perd 3/4 pour le good et l'extra

Les bonnes qualités sont encore plus rares cette année que l'année derniére et l'on eat & se Hemmnder at le coton née dégenére pas sar ce beau pays d'Egypte ot toutes' les/ptoditic- tions exotiques semblent devoir subir la loi de dégénérescence fatale. C'est 1A une question dont on devrait se préocoaper sérieusement, car elle pourrait gravémént cdtfipromettre I's venir de ce pays producteur de coton par excellence

Nous apprenons qu'ilest question de créer an Clearing House pour la compensation entre les agences des positions en contrate. Ce nouveau rouage simplifierait dans une large mesure les formalités nécessitées par les liquida- tions et réduirait l''usage du numéraire dans de fortes proportions. L/Assembl¢e Générale des Courtiers en marchandises est éonvoqade le 20 courant pour |'examen de ce projet.

Les différences de prix pour livraison sur contrate~de coten janvier sont fixées a P.T. 174 potir la Basse-Rgypte et P.T. 20 et 25 pour la Haate-Egypte et le Fayoum en plus de la pénalité habituelle qui est de P.T. 7 1/2.
La tendance du' marché est meilleure; ona toutes lesreisous. de croire que la situation économique et monétaire soit décidément otientée vers le retour des conditions normales.

div.head: Graines de Coton
div.p: Le marché. fait preuve de dispositions trés sdutenves. Les demandes sont fort nofbreuses pour |'Etranger. Le disponible clOture anjour d'bui a P.T. 71, soit en hausse de P.T. 1 sur vendredi dernier. Les graines Haate-Egypte edtent P.T. 70.

Les exportatiéns de la semaine sont presque le double de celles de l'année dernitre 4 la mé- tele époque, soit 221.993 contre 115.488 ardebs en 1907. Le stock est de 130.000 ardebs infé- ribur A celui de la dernitre campagne 4 pareille date.
Les engagements sont trés importants et l'on "pivoit pour ce mois-ci une exportation de 80,000 tennes, ce qui constituera an véritable revord.
Hull eat en forte hausse. Le dernier cours est dé £-615/16,en.avance de 7/16 sur la semaine dérniére.

Les affaires en contrats sont actives et les odurs reprennent & P. T. 76 pour le Février Mars. L'huile est soutenue.. L'exportation des tourteaux a été légtre. On prévoit néanmoins une certaine demande de cet article A la suite de la mauvaise récolte du mais.
Lesbesdias de la consommation qui sont con- sidérables, semblent vouloir favoriser l'avéne- | ment de prix plus hauts pour la graine de cotton.

div.head: WOMEN TALK TO WOMEN About Pe-ru-na
div.p: Depressed Feeling
Mrs. M. McGough, 919 W. 68rd street, New York, N. Y¥., writes:

"1 gladly add my mite of praise to Perana fof what it has done for me. Two éats Ago a depressed feeling took hold of me. My back and sides ached cootinually. My stomach got out of order so that at times I could not holds giaes of cold water. I didn't like to eat, affraid that my stomach would get sick. kL have been using Peruna for the three past months and now | feel as well as Lever did. 'My stomach is as strong asever and my nervous troubles have disappeared I keep recommending Peruna to my friends who are troutied as | was, and I have been thanked for doing so."
Mrs. Wilda-Moocers;»R. F. D. 1, Lents, Ore., member Order of Wash- ington, writes:

"For the past four years I was a wretched woman suffering with troubles peculiar to my sex, causing severe backache and bearing down pains and ledving me so weak and weary that it was only with dif- ficulty that 1 was able to attend to my household duties. I nsed differ- ent remedies and injections, but found no relief until I had tried Peruns. Within two weeks there was a complete change for the better anc in less than three months l was a welland happy woman and all the praise is due to Peruna,"
Headache and Backache
Mrs. Tressie Nelson, 609 N. 5th Ave., Nashville, Tenn,, writes:

"As Peruna has dofie mé a worl of good, I feel in duty bound to tell .of it, in hopes thatit may meet the eye of some woman who has suffered as [did. Por five years 1 really did net: know whats perfectly well day was, and if I did not have headache; I had backache or & pain somewhere snd really life was not worth the effort 1 made to keep going.
"A good friend advised me ta use Peruna and | was glad to try anything, and Iam very pleased to say. that six bottles made a oéw woman of me and have no more pains and life looks bright again."
The above testimonials represent actual experience of every-day life. They dre the truthful utterances of women who have been ill and have found a reliable remedy in Peruna.

It means a great deal to the women of America who have at hand a remedy capable of performilig sich cures. Nervousness, backache, dyspepsia, headache, melancholy, bearing down pains. All these and a host of other symptoms are relieved by Peruna. At least this is what the women say. They have no object in saying such things, except to render truthful testimony to their suffering sisters.
The reader will note by reading these testimonials that in most casesother | remedies were tried, doctors were consulted, and mally Peruna came to their rescue and made them well again.
Peruna is making such cures every day. It is the testimony of the people that has made Peruna so justly famous
Suffered Thirteen Years
Mrs. Anna Munden, Hollygrove, Ark., writes:
"I suffered with demale troubles for thirteen years.
"I saw an advertisement of your Peruna and bought one bottle and before I had taken it all I could get out of bed and walk about.
"After taking three bottles I was as well and hearty as ever and gained in flesh. I would not be without it.
Headache and Deafness
Mrs. mary E. Sampson, Londonderry, N.H., writes:

"I had terrible headaches, both ears runa nd I was nervous all the time, was deaf in one ear for thirty years. I took six bottles of Peruna and one of Manalin, and am happy to say that it is the best medicine that I ever heard of. I am not so nervous, my appetite is good, everything I eat agrees with me, and I am feeling better in every way."
A Severe Cold
Miss Marie Calvin, 927 Main Street, Cincinnati Ohio, writes:
"I caught a cold coming home from an evening party and as I did not pay particular attention to it, I quickly became worse and found myself in a serious condition.
"I took Peruna and it brought me immediate relief. Within a week I was cured and now whenever I feel badly Perude will set things right."

div.head: HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY S CONSULAR COURT AT ALEXANDRIA
div.p: Registration. 1908
Notice is hereby givers that all British subjects residing within the district of this consulate are bound to register themselves during the month of January.
All persons neglecting so to register them- selves are liable to fine or* imprisonment.
The Consulate will be open daily from 10 a.m. till noon for the delivery of registration certificates,
81707-6-2 By Order.

div.head: Administration dee Chemine de Fer - de PEtat
div.p: AVIS

L' Administration a I'honneur de porter 4 la connaissance do Public qu'une enchére publique par voie de "Kaimat-Mazad," sera ouverte le lundi, vingt Janvier, 1908, & neuf heures du matin au Service Central des Ma- gasins Généraux de Boulac (Caire) pour la vente de 70 (Soixante-dix) Tonnes environ de Vieux Fer, se trouvant au dépdt des ponts 4 Ramlet Boulac. On peut les y examiner chaque jonr de neuf heures da matin & une heure p-m. les Vendredis et jours fériés exceptés, et prendre connaissance des conditions de vente au bureau da Chef du Service des Magasins 4 Boulac (Caire) aux mémes heures que ci-dessus, les Dimanches et jours fériés exceptés,

Pour étre admis 4 concourir, le soumis- sionnaire devra, au préalable, verser A la Caisse Centrale. de | Administration an Caire une somme de L.E. 10 (Dix Livres Egyptien- nes) & titre de dépdt provisoire. Le soumis- sionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme -jasqu'A concurrence de 10 7 (dix pourcent) da montant de I'offre agréée et enlever 4 ses frais les lots qui lui seront adjugés dans un délai de vingt jours 4 comp- ter de la date de |'avis d'acceptation de son | offre.

Les offres pourront étre faites sur papier timbré de trente milliémes si l'intéressé ne peut pas assister aux enchéres publiques et 'dans ce cas la soumission ainsi qu'une co- pie du recn dan yersement du dépdt provi- soire seront adress¢es par la poste sous pli recommandé a :-— '

"Monsieur le Chef du Service des Magasins Généraux" des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat, Boulac, (Cuaire). et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant {la suseription suivante : "Offre ponr achat de vieux Fer."
Toute offre faite ou déposée ultérieurement au jour et a l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération.
L' Administration ne s'éngage pas & accepter les prix les plus éleyés ni & donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser la vente.
Le Caire, le 4 Janvier 1908.

div.head: Notice to Advertisers.
div.p: The "Egyptian Gazette" has given no adverting agency or company in Egypt any monopoly or exclusive right to act as advertising Agents on its behalf. Advertisements of every description are received at the offices of the "Gazette" from advertisers direct.
